Alan Ryan

Here, in the West, we have had our industrial/technological revolutions and achieved unprecedented prosperity at the cost of polluting the planet and devouring much of its natural resources.
 
 Now, cushioned by a surfeit of consumer appliances, automobility, etc, and a lavish life style made possible by the profligate use of energy, we are in a very comfortable position from which to lecture the "developing world" on green issues.
 
 In effect, we are saying to other countries, sorry chum, you must not aspire to our way of life nor follow in our footsteps and add your contribution to the problem of global warming. The resources on which our economies depend are on ration now (even for us) and there's hardly any cake left - so you must do without your share in the interests of preventing an environmental catastrophe that we have made likely.
 
 Isn't this a case of double standards ? The millions with little or nothing must remain in poverty so that the people with the lion's share can ease their consciences about the fate of the planet. Green hypocrisy ???
Duo_Maxwell

economically it's a bunch of bull****. 
 
 There isn't a single first world country who hasn't got to where it is now by not polluting badly. And it makes perfect sense. The economic incentives and benefits to pollute and industralize outweights the economic benefits of protecting the enviroment. Once a country hits a threshold, that slowly reverses and polluting past a specific point has a higher cost then benefit. Look at Mexico. It is reaching that threshold where industrial polluting is about to be outweighted by the advantages of the enviroment. If the history of every 1st world country holds true, polluting like mad is is the key to industrial sucess, which then leads to higher incentives to protect the enviroment. It's not only hypocracy, but bad economics.
Jo Bennett

What should happen is that the west cuts its emissions via technology and simultaneously supply the tech to developing nations so they can develop without screwing up any further. Basically we need to make the mother of all apologies to the developing world and help them develop sustainably. There isn't another option.
Alan Ryan

 It seems most unlikely that China (another example) will pay much, if any, attention to the "green conscience" as it strives to reach Western levels of prosperity. If "unacceptable" (in Western opinion) pollution is a necessary by-product of driving the Chinese economy forward, then it's just too bad for the environment. 
 
 It's probable that other developing countries, if they get the chance, will take the same view and resist the admonitions of first world countries who can afford the luxury of Green Party preachers.
Jo Bennett
What I'm saying is that the west is effectively going to have to subsidise the develping world so that it is more efficient for them to develop sustainably.
Alan Ryan

I'm not sure that China counts as being among the developing world. It's most unlikely that Western money will be found to subsidise the Chinese economy while it evolves more "sustainable" ways of maintaining itself after a satisfactory level of prosperity has been achieved. 
 
 I quite like the word "sustainable" - it has a nice sincere ring to it, and has been added to the lexicon of buzz words that characterise discussions about the environment, global warming, etc. But what does it actually mean in terms of making the benefits of our energy voracious economies available to developing nations in the near future ?
 
 The peoples of Africa (for example) don't want pie in the sky: they want pie on the table, and they want it now.
Jo Bennett

In the short term it means not using too much pesticide and not overplanting, education about soil erosion is also important. Medium term it means local energy production from renewable sources, something that is actually far more logical for a lot of villages. Power infrastructure is damn expensive for large countries with relatively small, dispersed population. Population control is also important. China has a handle on this, but all countries, rich and poor, at least need to stabilise thier population.
zelma

West is not the only place that pollution and extravagance is practiced. In the United Arab Emirates, the people stand at the gas pump, talking on their cell phones and literally pour gasoline on the ground as well as pour oil and contaminants into the Persian Gulf on a daily basis. There is constant building and rebuilding of skyscrapers for the purpose of spending money because there is so much money. I visited the UAE while my husband worked on a offshore drilling rig--and witnessed this for myself.
 
 China has always identified with the third world countries and I really don't think China is too interested in our ecology speeches, but rather our technology. And Bill Clinton already gave them all the info they wanted.
 
 It is not the United States place to subsidize the world. The people in the US who live millionaire lives are politicians, hollywood film stars, and a few people like Howard Hughes......and that is not mainstream America.
Dzeron

Environmentalism is hypocritical in more ways than one. Their very philosophy is, "Humans are too stupid to take care of the planet, so it is necessary that some stupid humans tell the other stupid humans how to take care of the planet."
 
 Come on! Anyone with half a brain can see through this fraud.
Jo Bennett

Surely the history of the last 100 years or so makes it demonstrably clear that through ignorance we haven't looked after the planet very well? I don't know about you but I'm inclined to listen when a scientist tells me that pumping raw sewage into the oceans isn't such a good plan. People will live in a surprising amount of ****, not doing anything about it, until they are told it is harmful. Witness wells too close to cess pits in 19th century cities, for example.
Alan Ryan

Western societies, the beneficiaries of the scientific revolution, have developed a complex infrastructure of transportation, communications, medical care, educational facilities, and so on - all of which consume, either directly or indirectly, enormous amounts of energy. If or when the supply of this energy is severely rationed or comes to an end, there will be a social calamity that could see a return of political extremism. 
 
 It has taken the labour and ingenuity of many generations to achieve our present levels of prosperity: it is wishful thinking at best, to imagine that we will voluntarily abandon the benefits of living in the 21st century and choose to turn back the clock in order to "save the planet". 
 
 Exhortations (from environmentalists) to the millions of people who have not yet had the "life chances" that rest upon an infrastructure similar to the Western model, will fall on deaf ears. There is no short cut from their misery to our plenty. It is pure humbug to pretend that the economic future for, say, Africa rests upon wind farms, solar power, and suchlike.
Jo Bennett

There are savings to be made through efficiency without significant penalties to standards of living. For example, most cars could manage perfectly well with smaller engines, especially using modern materials to make them lighter. A combination of this and replacing substantial chunks of our energy supply with renewables (even if all is not possible) and substantial reforestation could make it possible to maintain and improve living standards while reducing environmental damage. We don't have to eliminate carbon emissions, just make the level of production sustainable. It will be difficult, I don't doubt it, but I don't see what is wrong with saying we should try. Should we just not bother because you think we won't succeed? When the alternative is billions dead as a result of climate change?
Alan Ryan

 You do not address any of the points I've made about the hypocrisy of making the developing world wait for an indefinite period while environmentally friendly sources of energy are engineered - and which will be adequate to achieving the standard of living to which they aspire.
 
 It is a weakness in your argument to suggest that my opinion could affect the objective situation in any way whatever. Your final sentence is a conclusion so emotively charged that I won't ask you how you arrive at it.

I never understood the RUSH to exploit natural resources. Its merely so someone somewhere can get rich fast before someone else does.

 The rush to exploit natural resources was/ is certainly driven by an ultimate profit motive; this applies most obviously in industrialised societies or in developing societies attempting to industrialise. But this oversimplifies a bit. Lots of natural resources have been devoured just in order to survive or to create a subsistence society.
 
 Usually, but not always, these resources are renewables: I'm thinking here of the forests that have been cut down for firewood and to make land available for arable farming or animal husbandry. Sometimes the results are catastrophic damage to ecosystems with, for instance, erosion creating local deserts.
